articles.headline: That Fresh Look, Genetically Buffed
articles.snippet: Some members of the United States apple industry say the introduction of genetically engineered fruit could undermine the apple’s image as a healthy, natural food.
articles.abstract: Some members of the United States apple industry say the introduction of genetically engineered fruit could undermine the apple’s image as a healthy, natural food.
articles.lead_paragraph: A small company is trying to bring to market a genetically engineered apple that does not turn brown when sliced or bruised. But it has much of the rest of the apple industry seeing red.

articles.headline: In China, Little Urge to Audit the Auditors
articles.snippet: In recent months, China has made it harder for American investors to check the legitimacy of their Chinese investments.
articles.abstract: In recent months, China has made it harder for American investors to check the legitimacy of their Chinese investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: Optimism appears to be rising that the Securities and Exchange Commission can reach some sort of accommodation with Chinese authorities to get help in investigating a wave of frauds at Chinese-based companies. The deceits have humiliated auditors and money managers who trusted or vouched for the companies, while enriching short-sellers who spotted the frauds early.

articles.headline: In Latest Data on Economy, Experts See Signs of Pickup
articles.snippet: A range of experts say the economy should improve somewhat in the coming months because of lower oil prices and industries like autos and housing.
articles.abstract: A range of experts say the economy should improve somewhat in the coming months because of lower oil prices and industries like autos and housing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Despite the recent run of disappointing economic data, a broad range of experts and forecasters expect the economy to improve slightly in coming months, thanks to lower oil prices and new signs of life from sectors like automobiles and housing.

articles.headline: Service to Israel Tugs at Identity of Arab Citizens
articles.snippet: The issue of Arab civilian service to Israel has revived the raw, decades-old conundrum of what it means to be both Arab and Israeli.
articles.abstract: The issue of Arab civilian service to Israel has revived the raw, decades-old conundrum of what it means to be both Arab and Israeli.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAZARETH, Israel — Three young Palestinian women sat on the floor at a summer camp this week surrounded by Legos and 3-year-olds. As the toddlers played, the women taught them the color of each block, repeating the words in Arabic, azrak for blue or akhdar for green.

articles.headline: Bankruptcy in California Isn’t Seen as a Trend
articles.snippet: Despite the fact that San Bernardino is the third city in the state to move toward bankruptcy this year, investors in municipal debt showed little sign of concern.
articles.abstract: Despite the fact that San Bernardino is the third city in the state to move toward bankruptcy this year, investors in municipal debt showed little sign of concern.
articles.lead_paragraph: As San Bernardino, Calif., moved toward bankruptcy this week, municipal bond analysts were questioning how widespread the fiscal distress may prove to be, but were not predicting a wave of defaults.

articles.headline: U.S. Pursuing a Middleman in Web Piracy
articles.snippet: The government’s antipiracy case against Richard O’Dwyer is unusual because he did not publish pirated content himself but pointed the way for others.
articles.abstract: The government’s antipiracy case against Richard O’Dwyer is unusual because he did not publish pirated content himself but pointed the way for others.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard O’Dwyer, an enterprising 24-year-old college student from northern England, has found himself in the middle of a fierce battle between two of America’s great exports: Hollywood and the Internet.

articles.headline: Candidates Racing for Future, Gaze Fixed Firmly on the Past
articles.snippet: The two contenders for the White House and their allies are spending their time and energy relitigating old fights rather than focusing on new ideas for the next four years.
articles.abstract: The two contenders for the White House and their allies are spending their time and energy relitigating old fights rather than focusing on new ideas for the next four years.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s re-election slogan is “Forward.” But the campaigns he and Mitt Romney are waging these days might be more accurately described as “Backward.”

articles.headline: Fresh From Syria, Rebel Commanders Unite in Frustration
articles.snippet: A meeting in Turkey near Syria’s northern border spoke volumes about the priorities of Syrian fighting groups, which are focused on the basics of war against President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.abstract: A meeting in Turkey near Syria’s northern border spoke volumes about the priorities of Syrian fighting groups, which are focused on the basics of war against President Bashar al-Assad.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANTAKYA, Turkey — Abu Moayed, a commander in an armed Syrian opposition brigade, stood and waved his arms emphatically at the fellow rebel commanders who filled the sweltering room.
